description: A British Indian variant of saraf, from Urdu صراف‎ (sarrāf) and Persian صراف‎ (sarâf), from Arabic صَرَّاف‎ (ṣarrāf).

entries.meaning: (India) A provider of financial services, especially a small-scale independent banker or money changer or (historical) a local expert at detecting bad coin.
examples: The sheraffs are poore and begerly.

entries.meaning: (Hong Kong) A cashier, especially for a carpark.
examples: An assistant shroff of the Queen Mary Hospital faced Mr. J. Reynolds at Central yesterday charged with the larceny of $10.

entries.meaning: (Hong Kong) Short for shroff office: the office of a shroff at a carpark, etc.

verbs.description: shroff (third-person singular simple present shroffs, present participle shroffing, simple past and past participle shroffed)

entries.meaning: (India, transitive) To act as a shroff, especially (historical) to inspect coins to detect debasement, counterfeits, clipping, etc. for a commission.
examples: I represented... that the money could not be divided till it was shroffed.
